messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...>
wrote:
>
> David wrote:
>
> > Yes, it is true, but it is a hard assumption, because you need a
> > third library to get this behavior. A testing framework should
> > provide this case, without using another one library.
>
> Now you're making the hard assumption: that what you're doing is
> commonly needed. A framework of any kind should solve common
problems
> and leave unusual ones to extensions. This is the difference
between
> "framework" and "platform".

Dear J.B. Rainsberger,

It is a metter of opinion, the question is simple: ¿Can I change
dinamically during a jUnit test the classpath?

The answer you provide instead of saying NO, :-) is: use Ant. ¿Why?

Under jUnit, I can modify life cicle of the running process in order
to make tests, why not to let the user to alter also some
configuration information for example: classpath (and probably it is
possible, specifying some class loader mechanism, but I am not an
expert on that)

I don't like test that depends on IDE's, because when the project
grows up you end up that is much better to run them under console,
that is why I don't like to assume specific location of Eclipse
classpath.

Thanks any way for your interest,

David
